title: Honey, I shrank the data! Synology unveils tiny, awesome storage unit
text:
And, in a small office where you’re working with Word documents and the like, it’s arguably preferable to use the cloud for your files. With a NAS device, you’re going to need off-site storage, anyway, just in case the office burns down, so why not cut out the middle man and store your work files direct to internet?

But on the other hand, cloud companies such as Google and Amazon do tend to be evil and at risk of data breaches, and it might be that you’re loathe to trust them with all your secret files.

It may be teeny weeny on the outside, but it’s absolutely huge in terms of its capabilities.

Or it might be that you have too many files taking up too much space to make cloud storage a viable option, thus making a NAS a vital addition to your digital life.

I’d never put all my photos onto the cloud, for instance. There are too many of them, and they are too private, so instead I store them on a NAS in my home, which I sync securely over the internet to a NAS in someone else’s home, just in case my house burns down.

Photos, photos and more photos... you might well run out of cloud storage in any case. AP

In any event, the Synology DS620slim is so much more than a NAS, it might be worth considering even if you’re on the fence about your need for centralised storage in your home or office.

The Synology operating system that runs on the device, known as “DSM”, has a Package Centre with a vast number of apps in it, ranging from geeky security and authorisation servers such as OAuth and Radius, to office productivity services such as in-house chat (if you really don’t trust cloud-based chat services) and word processing – apps that use the storage in the NAS, but which aren’t really about storage.

You’ll struggle to find some server-style application you won’t be able to run on this device.

The operating system also runs Docker, an application container system that’s incredibly popular in tech circles, so even if you can’t find a DSM app to suit your needs, you’ll almost always be able to find a Dockerised version of the app which, with a bit of know-how, you’ll be able to run on the device.

Advertisement

We’ve got a home automation system known as OpenHAB running in Docker on the DS620slim, for turning the lights on and off here in the Labs, and it’s running flawlessly. We’ve also got the Plex media server running nicely in Docker on the DS620slim, not because we couldn’t find it in the DSM app store, but because we wanted more control over which version of Plex we ran.

Which is to say, you’ll struggle to find some server-style application you won’t be able to run on this device. It may be teeny weeny on the outside, roughly the size of a half-loaf of sliced bread (making it about a third the size of a regular NAS), but it's absolutely huge in terms of its capabilities.

The DS620slim even comes with Synology’s Virtual Machine Manager, which lets you run virtual Windows, Linux and other computers inside the tiny box, in the rare case you need to do something that can’t be done in DSM or in Docker.

Be warned, though: the review unit we were sent had only 2 gigabytes of memory in it, and only 192 megabytes of that is available to run virtual machines. That’s not nearly enough memory. Even a lightweight operating system such as Ubuntu Server has a recommended minimum memory requirement of 512 megabytes, so if you’re even thinking about using the Virtual Machine Manager, make sure you upgrade the memory. We couldn’t get Ubuntu Server, much less Windows Server, running on our test unit.

Unless you’re using your NAS for huge video files, we don’t see the performance as an issue.

Speedwise, the thing is about as fast as the DS1817+ we reviewed previously. Our test unit came with two solid-state drives, which combined with its very decent Intel processor should make the DS620slim very zippy indeed for uploading and downloading files. But it’s only got a 1 Gbps ethernet connection to your network, which seemed to cap its performance in our tests.

Unless you’re using your NAS for huge video files, however, we don’t see the performance as an issue. Most users would probably be connected to their network via Wi-Fi, and it’s the Wi-Fi connection that would limit the speed they’d experience, not the ethernet connection between the Wi-Fi router and the DS620slim.

If storage performance really is an issue, though, you probably should steer clear of this itsy bitsy little NAS, and get something (such as the DS187+, or something newer) that lets you add a lightning-fast network connection.

That something else would probably be a lot bigger than the DS620slim, but never mind! You can always sit it on the floor under a desk, or in a cupboard somewhere. Anywhere with a bit of ventilation.

Size has never been much of an issue with NAS devices, anyhow, which does make us wonder why Synology bothered shrinking the DS620slim in the first place.

I guess it’s like shrinking Twisties packets. Because you can. Because it’s fun. And because, if things really do start to heat up in your house, like an oven, you can always just grab this little NAS with one hand and make a run for it.

SYNOLOGY DS620SLIM

Likes Fast enough; huge number of great apps

Dislikes Not enough memory for the most advanced usage

Price $849 plus cost of disks
description: Do you have too many files taking up too much space to make cloud storage a viable option? This little device could be a vital addition to your digital life.
